ourBeliefs.content2: We believe that the random nature of sports has a unique power to bring people together. In a world filled with conflicts and divisions, our events offer a chance to unite humankind. By competing together, we demonstrate that athletic challenges can bridge cultures, nations, and beliefs, showing that competition can foster connection instead of division.
ourBeliefs.content3: Everyone is welcome to participate, regardless of nationality, race, values, religion, political views, gender, or sexual orientation. Our host cities ensure that all participants can join by providing the necessary support, including visas. We stand firmly against any form of exclusion based on identity, beliefs, religion, race, gender, or any other defining trait, ensuring equal opportunity for everyone.
ourBeliefs.content4: Transparency is at the heart of everything we do. As far as possible, we use open-source technology for payments and communication to ensure openness and security. Our democratic system gives equal rights and voting power to every nation and participant, fostering a fair, accountable, and inclusive environment for all.

CFR.title2: Can a supporter of a campaign attend the Randolympics ?
CFR.title5: Who can participate as an athlete? The only requirements are that you have a valid passport and are at least 15 years old. There's no upper age limit, so no one is too old or too young to join!
CFR.title6: How can I get more supporters for my campaign ?
CFR.title7: Why is there a minimum support amount of USD 1?
CFR.title8: How do you verify that each supporter is unique?
CFR.title9: Can I create more than one campaign?
CFR.title10: Can I be both an athlete and a supporter at the same time?
CFR.title11: What happens to the money raised through donations?
CFR.title12: How does a celebrity campaign differ from a normal campaign?
CFR.title13: What campaign will succeed? How does the National Ranking work?
CFR.title14: What happens if athletes cannot attend due to injury or personal reasons?
CFR.content1: Yes, absolutely! Everyone is welcome to join and be a part of this incredible adventure. Supporters, friends, and fans are all encouraged to come and cheer on their athletes, experience the excitement, and enjoy the community atmosphere.
CFR.content2: Anyone can start a campaign! All you need is a friend who believes in you and at least one dollar to get started. It's a simple way to motivate someone to achieve extraordinary goals
CFR.content3: Anyone can participate as an athlete! The only requirements are that you have a valid passport and are at least 15 years old. There’s no upper age limit, so no one is too old or too young to join!
CFR.content4: To gather more supporters, share your campaign on social media, send personalized messages to your network on WhatsApp, and spread the word in your gym, sports club, or community. The more people know, the more they can support!
CFR.content5: This small minimum amount is a safeguard against fake or automated accounts. It helps ensure that each supporter is a real, unique person genuinely interested in backing an athlete.
CFR.content6: We verify each athlete through their valid passport, ensuring that there is no way to manipulate the system or create duplicate entries.
CFR.content7: Yes, you can create as many campaigns as you want! Starting a campaign is a huge compliment to a friend—a sign that you believe in their potential to achieve extraordinary things. Campaigns also make a thoughtful and inspiring gift for special occasions, like birthdays.
CFR.content8: Yes, you can! You can participate as an athlete in a campaign set up by your friend while also creating multiple campaigns yourself to support others. Your involvement can be as broad and supportive as you want it to be.
CFR.content9: If the campaign is successful, the raised money will be transferred to the athlete to support their journey to the Randolympics, including training, equipment, and other preparation expenses. Additionally, if supporters wish to attend the event, up to three supporters from the campaign will receive a contribution towards their flight tickets to help them be part of the experience. If the campaign does not succeed in getting the athlete into an event, the donations will be used to ensure the event runs smoothly and is well-funded.
CFR.content10: A celebrity campaign is similar to a normal campaign, but with a few key differences. Unlike regular campaigns, the contact details and email address of the celebrity may not be known to the person creating the campaign. If the celebrity decides to consider attending the Randolympics and wants to log in to their account, they need to announce their interest on social media and then contact both the National President and the campaign creator. They will coordinate and provide a secure login method for the celebrity to access their campaign account safely.
CFR.content11: A campaign's success depends on its position in the National Ranking, which is determined through a randomized ranking process. Each campaign is ranked based on three factors: the total amount of money raised, the number of unique supporters, and a random number between 0 and 1. These factors are combined to generate a final ranking for each campaign. To form each National Team, the top 50 men and top 50 women with the highest rankings are selected. However, teams must be balanced regarding weight categories, with each of the three weight groups equally represented. This balance requirement means that a campaign ranked 48th might not make the team if that weight category is already filled, while a campaign ranked 53rd could be included if that weight group is underrepresented.
CFR.content12: If an athlete in the top 50 cannot attend the Randolympics due to injury, personal reasons, or other circumstances, they will be replaced by the next highest-ranked athlete from their weight category. This ensures that the team remains balanced and filled. Athletes ranked just above 50 still have a chance to participate if there are dropouts or changes in the roster, providing opportunities for those with a slightly lower ranking to make it to the games.
CFR.content13: Not directly from the Randolympics organization, but each athlete is free to sign sponsorship agreements. Unlike other events, there are no restrictions on how athletes dress or what brands they can display and when. Some events might go viral, and an athlete could become famous for a specific competition, opening up more sponsorship and earning opportunities.

EC.title16: Can athletes request to change their assigned sports?
EC.title18: How many sports are assigned to an athlete?
EC.title19: What types of sports will be included in the Randolympics?
EC.title20: What kind of training support is provided to athletes before the competition?
EC.title21: Are there any specific rules that athletes need to follow during competitions?
EC.title22: What is the event structure or setup?
EC.title23: What safety measures are in place for competitions?
EC.title24: Can supporters participate in any events or activities?
EC.content14: No, once sports are assigned during the opening ceremony, they cannot be changed. The random assignment is part of the challenge and spirit of the Randolympics.
EC.content15: No, participation in any competition is entirely voluntary. We prioritize the safety and well-being of all athletes. If an athlete feels uncomfortable or unprepared for any assigned sport, they are not required to compete. Our goal is to encourage participation and challenge limits, but never at the cost of an athlete's comfort or safety.
EC.content16: It depends, but typically an athlete will be assigned between 4 to 6 sports to compete in during the Randolympics.
EC.content17: The event will feature a wide range of sports, including endurance, strength, team-based, and individual competitions. The list on our webpage here might change as we get closer to the event.
EC.content18: Each athlete is responsible for their own training. Support from their campaign and community is encouraged.
EC.content19: Yes, each sport has its own set of rules and regulations that must be followed to ensure fair play. These rules will be explained in detail before each competition.
EC.content20: In every competition, each country is represented by one team or athlete. There are three types of events:
EC.content21: Races like marathons: These allow up to 64 competitors in one race, resulting in a single winner.
EC.content22: Team sports like football or tennis: These are structured in a knockout format where winners advance to the next round until only four teams or athletes remain.
EC.content23: Races with heats like swimming: These involve multiple rounds with heats, leading to a final race to determine the winner.
EC.content24: All competitions are overseen by referees and safety officers. There will be medical staff on-site, and equipment will be inspected to ensure it meets safety standards.
EC.content25: Supporters are encouraged to participate in designated fan events and activities during the Randolympics. However, they cannot compete in the official sports events unless they are registered athletes.
EC.content26: We aim to plan sufficient time between two competitions to ensure athletes have time to rest and prepare. However, in extreme situations—such as a delay in the first competition and a traffic jam between venues—it is theoretically possible that an athlete may not be able to compete in the second event. Having good support can help manage such situations by quickly finding the venue and organizing transportation to minimize disruptions in such unlikely events.

SPM.title26: Who will have the broadcasting rights?
SPM.title27: How can I become a partner or sponsor?
SPM.title29: Can sponsors have exclusive rights to specific events?
SPM.title30: What branding opportunities are available for sponsors?
SPM.title31: Can media outlets report on the Randolympics without purchasing broadcasting rights?
SPM.content27: The broadcasting rights for the Randolympics will soon be sold in an online auction. This auction will sell the rights for each event in the main languages. After purchasing, the entity or person who acquires these rights will have the exclusive ability to report in that language from the event.
SPM.content28: We welcome potential partners and sponsors to join us in making the Randolympics a global success. If you are interested, please contact us through our Partner Inquiry Page for more information and to discuss opportunities.
SPM.content29: Sponsorship opportunities range from event sponsorships and digital content integration to on-site activations. We offer flexible packages tailored to the needs and goals of each sponsor. Contact us to explore how we can create a unique sponsorship package for your brand.
SPM.content30: Yes, sponsors can secure exclusive rights to specific events within the Randolympics. This includes branding, digital presence, and other unique promotional opportunities during the event. However, athletes retain the right to have their own sponsorships and display personal branding on their gear and uniforms.
SPM.content31: Sponsors can showcase their brands through event banners, digital streams, and social media channels. While event branding is available, keep in mind that athletes can feature their own sponsors and brands on their uniforms and during personal media appearances.
SPM.content32: Media outlets are welcome to cover the Randolympics through general news reporting. However, for live broadcasts or detailed event coverage in a specific language, they must acquire broadcasting rights through the auction process.

LCG.title33: How is the Global President elected?
LCG.title35: How are athletes selected for the Randolympics?
LCG.title36: How do we try to avoid corruption?
LCG.title38: What is the governance structure of Randolympics?
LCG.title39: How is compliance maintained within Randolympics?
LCG.content33: National Presidents are elected by athletes with an ongoing campaign and a valid passport for that country. If a candidate receives more than 120% of the votes compared to the current National President, the new candidate takes over the position.
LCG.content34: The Global President is elected similarly to the National Presidents, but in this case, the electors are the National Presidents from each country. A candidate must receive a vote total exceeding 120% of the current Global President's votes to be elected.
LCG.content35: Managers are selected by the Global President. The President appoints managers to various roles within the organization based on their expertise and the needs of Randolympics.
LCG.content36: Athletes are selected through a randomized national ranking system. This ranking considers the total amount of money raised, the number of unique supporters, and a random number to ensure a fair and balanced selection process.
LCG.content37: We aim to prevent corruption by ensuring maximum transparency. All payments, contracts, and financial agreements are made open and accessible to the public to maintain trust and accountability.
LCG.content38: We strive to execute as many transactions as possible via a blockchain. This ensures that all financial movements are traceable, verifiable, and secure, providing a high level of transparency.
LCG.content39: The governance structure of Randolympics includes the Global President, National Presidents, and appointed managers who oversee various functions of the organization. This structure ensures both global oversight and local representation, fostering fair and transparent management.
LCG.content40: Compliance is maintained through a set of established rules and guidelines that all participants, managers, and officials must follow. Regular audits and reviews are conducted to ensure adherence to these rules and to uphold the integrity of the Randolympics.

seventhScreen.content19: We are a group of sport enthusiasts from Stockholm, Sweden. Our mission is to get together other sport fans, amateur athletes and all others doing sports recreationally who wish to take part in Randolympics that will be organized July 8th - July 16th, 2028 in Stockholm. Randolympics are just like regular Olympics, but organized for ordinary people who would like to test their strength and stamina in sports ranging from archery and wrestling to field hockey and golf, both in a group and/or individually.

campaign.infoPopupCouponText:
If you have coupon code, you can make a donation using only coupon code, without needing to pay with real money (credit card, paypal).

If you don't have coupon code, you can proceed Next, to pay with credit card (paypal) only.

You can use only national coupon codes to make coupon-only donation to campaign. National coupon codes apply depending in what country athlete of campaign is located in.

So, campaign for athlete who is located in Sweden, you can use only Sweden national coupon codes to make coupon-only donation to campaign.

As well, using coupon code, you can have addition to payment you make.

Types of coupon codes: National and Global
All coupon codes are 6 characters (which can be anything, doesn't determine it's value), but they have a type, which determines how much addition will be applied to donation.

National coupon code - coupon of fixed price value. E.g. SWED12 can be coupon name (6 chars), that will add 10$ to payment. If donation is done coupon-only then donation is done just by inserting donation code, and that's 10$ donation for that friend campaign. If on other hand, you insert this coupon code, and click Next, and proceed to insert credit card or Paypal amount you want to donate, then 10$ of coupon code value will be added to payment you make. So, if you make 5$ payment donation with credit card (or paypal), then together with national coupon, your donation will be calcualted as 15$ (10$ + 5$ = 15$)

Global coupon code - coupon of percentage value, depending on your payment (credit card, paypal). E.g. In this case coupon code can be RAND18, and it's value is 50%. So that means, 50% is added onto payment you make via credit card (paypal). So, if you make 5$ payment donation via credit card or paypal, then your actual donation will be calculated as 7.5$ (5$ + 50% = 7.5$)(50% of 5$ )

archery.subtitle1: Tests precision, focus, and technique in both individual and team formats.
archery.title1: Brief Overview of the Basic Rules for Archery
archery.desc1:
Distance: Shooting distances vary depending on the competition format and category.

Equipment: Archers must use approved bows and arrows. Equipment must meet specific regulations regarding size and materials.

Safety: Archers must follow safety protocols, including proper handling of equipment and maintaining a safe distance from the target area.

These rules ensure accuracy, fairness, and safety in archery competitions.

variations.title: Individual Archery
variations.desc:
Event: Archers compete individually to shoot arrows at a target from a set distance.
Competition Method: Each archer takes a series of shots at the target, aiming for the highest score based on accuracy. Points are awarded based on where the arrows land on the target, with the bullseye earning the highest points.

variations.title: Team Archery
variations.desc:
Event: Teams of archers compete together, with each team member taking shots to accumulate a combined score.
Competition Method: Teams shoot in rounds, with each member contributing to the total team score. The team with the highest combined score wins.
Scoring: Each team's score is the sum of the individual scores from each member’s shots.

swimming.subtitle1: Swimming test speed, technique, and endurance across different distances and strokes.
swimming.title1: Brief Overview of the Basic Rules for competitive swimming
swimming.desc1:
False Starts: A swimmer who leaves the starting block before the signal will be disqualified.

Turns and Finishes: Proper technique for turns and finishes must be followed for each stroke.

Underwater Distance: Swimmers cannot stay underwater beyond 15 meters after the start and each turn.

These rules ensure fairness, safety, and consistency in swimming competitions.

1. Freestyle: Any stroke is allowed, but the front crawl is typically used.
Swimmers must touch the wall at each turn and finish.
Part of the swimmer's body must break the surface throughout the race, except at the start and turns.

2. Backstroke: Swimmers must stay on their back except during turns.
They start in the water and push off the wall.
Flip turns are allowed, but swimmers must touch the wall on their back at the finish.

3. Breaststroke: Swimmers use simultaneous arm and leg movements (frog kick).
Both hands must touch the wall at the same time during turns and finishes.
The head must break the surface of the water during each stroke cycle.

4. Butterfly Both arms must move forward simultaneously over the water, with a dolphin kick.
Both hands must touch the wall at the same time during turns and finishes.

5. Individual Medley (IM) Swimmers perform each stroke (butterfly, backstroke, breaststroke, freestyle) in the correct order.
They must touch the wall at each stroke transition.

6. Relays The swimmer in the pool must touch the wall before the next swimmer can start.
In medley relays, the stroke order is backstroke, breaststroke, butterfly, and freestyle.

variations.title: 50m Freestyle
variations.desc: A sprint race covering one pool length in a freestyle stroke, typically front crawl. Speed is critical.

variations.title: 100m Freestyle
variations.desc: Two lengths using freestyle stroke, a balance of speed and endurance.

variations.title: 200m Freestyle
variations.desc: Four pool lengths in freestyle, requiring strong pacing and efficient turns.

variations.title: 400m Freestyle
variations.desc: Eight lengths of the pool, emphasising endurance in freestyle.

variations.title: 1500m Freestyle
variations.desc: A long-distance event (30 lengths) in freestyle, requiring consistent pacing and stamina.

variations.title: 100m Backstroke
variations.desc: Two lengths of the pool in backstroke, where swimmers must start in the water facing the wall, using an alternating arm motion.

variations.title: 200m Backstroke
variations.desc: Four pool lengths using backstroke, focusing on maintaining strong technique and endurance.

variations.title: 100m Breaststroke
variations.desc: Two lengths using the breaststroke technique, with a frog-like kick and glide, emphasizing power and timing.

variations.title: 200m Breaststroke
variations.desc: Four lengths of breaststroke, demanding endurance while maintaining a smooth and powerful stroke.

variations.title: 100m Butterfly
variations.desc: Two lengths using butterfly stroke, characterized by simultaneous arm movements and a dolphin-like kick.

variations.title: 200m Butterfly
variations.desc: A longer event of four pool lengths in butterfly, requiring excellent rhythm and endurance.

variations.title: 200m Individual Medley
variations.desc: Four pool lengths where each stroke is swum for 50 meters: butterfly, backstroke, breaststroke, and freestyle.

variations.title: 400m Individual Medley
variations.desc: Eight lengths of the pool with each stroke swum for 100 meters in the same order: butterfly, backstroke, breaststroke, and freestyle.

variations.title: 4x100m Freestyle Relay
variations.desc: Four swimmers each swim 100m in freestyle. The next swimmer can start when the previous swimmer touches the wall.

variations.title: 4x200m Freestyle Relay
variations.desc: A longer relay where each swimmer swims 200m in freestyle.

variations.title: 4x100m Medley Relay
variations.desc: Four swimmers, each swimming one of the strokes in this order: backstroke, breaststroke, butterfly, and freestyle.

diving.subtitle1: Diving is a sport that combines athleticism, precision, and grace as athletes perform acrobatic jumps and flips from springboards or platforms, entering the water with minimal splash. The sport requires control, body awareness, and impeccable timing.
diving.desc1:
Divers are scored based on the difficulty of their dive and how well they execute it, considering factors like takeoff, flight, and entry into the water.

Dive Difficulty: Divers choose a list of dives, each assigned a degree of difficulty (DD) based on complexity. More difficult dives offer the potential for higher scores but also carry greater risk.

Judging: A panel of judges scores each dive based on execution and technique. Points are awarded for the takeoff, the aerial phase, and entry into the water.

Splash Control: A key element in diving is the entry into the water. A well-executed dive minimizes splash, as a cleaner entry is considered more controlled and aesthetically pleasing.

Diving is a test of both physical prowess and artistic presentation, with athletes combining athletic jumps, flips, and twists in a captivating display of skill.

variations.title: 3m Springboard Diving
variations.desc:
Athletes dive from a flexible board 3 meters above the water. The board allows divers to gain height with their jump, adding complexity to their dive.
Key Skills: Balance, precision, and control during takeoff and mid-air maneuvers.
Scoring: Judges evaluate the approach, execution of twists and somersaults, and entry into the water with minimal splash.

variations.title: 10m Platform Diving
variations.desc:
Athletes dive from a solid platform 10 meters above the water. With no spring action, height is generated purely by the athlete's push-off.
Key Skills: Power, precision, and body control to execute flips and twists from a greater height.
Scoring: Judges focus on form during takeoff, aerial execution, and clean water entry.

variations.title: Synchronized 3m Springboard Diving
variations.desc:
Two divers perform the same dive from separate springboards, aiming for perfect synchronization.
Key Skills: Timing, coordination, and synchronization between the divers, along with individual dive technique.
Scoring: Scores reflect both the execution of the dive and the synchronization of the athletes.

variations.title: Synchronized 10m Platform Diving:
variations.desc:
Similar to the synchronized springboard event, but performed from the 10m platform.
Key Skills: Timing and synchronization in a high-difficulty event, with emphasis on both athletes mirroring each other's movements in the air.
Scoring: Judges evaluate synchronization and individual execution of the dive.

synchronized_swim.subtitle1: Synchronized Swimming (now called Artistic Swimming) combines swimming, dance, and gymnastics, where athletes perform intricate, choreographed routines in the water to music. The sport demands strength, endurance, flexibility, grace, and precise timing, with athletes needing to perform both underwater and above the surface.
synchronized_swim.desc1:
Synchronized Swimming (now called Artistic Swimming) combines swimming, dance, and gymnastics, where athletes perform intricate, choreographed routines in the water to music. The sport demands strength, endurance, flexibility, grace, and precise timing, with athletes needing to perform both underwater and above the surface.

Routines: Both events consist of technical and free routines. The technical routine includes required elements, while the free routine allows more creativity and expression.

Judging: Judges award points for technical execution (precision of movements, difficulty) and artistic impression (creativity, choreography, and synchronization with the music).

Underwater Skills: Athletes must hold their breath for extended periods while maintaining graceful movements underwater.

Synchronized swimming demands exceptional athleticism, with athletes needing to master both endurance and artistry to execute flawless routines.

variations.title: Synchronized Swimming (Duet) - 2
variations.desc:
Two swimmers perform a choreographed routine set to music, showcasing synchronization and artistry.
Key Skills: Precise synchronization between the swimmers, strong technical execution, flexibility, and creative expression.
Scoring: Judges score based on technical merit (execution of movements, lifts, and transitions) and artistic impression (choreography, creativity, and musical interpretation). Synchronization between the two swimmers is crucial.

variations.title: Synchronized Swimming (Team) - 8
variations.desc:
A team of eight swimmers performs a routine set to music, often featuring complex patterns, lifts, and formations.
Key Skills: Perfect coordination among all team members, strength in executing lifts and stunts, endurance, and synchronization in both large and small groups.
Scoring: Teams are judged on their technical execution, synchronization, and artistic impression. The complexity of formations, transitions, and lifts adds to the difficulty and potential scoring.

athletics.subtitle1: Athletics is a collection of sporting events that involve running, jumping, throwing, and walking. It is one of the most popular and diverse categories in the world of sports, featuring events that test speed, strength, endurance, and technique. Athletics competitions can be held both indoors and outdoors, with the Olympics and World Championships being the premier events.
athletics.desc1:
False Starts: In sprints, a false start occurs when an athlete leaves the starting blocks before the gun sounds, resulting in disqualification.

Throws and Jumps: Athletes must perform within designated areas. In jumps, they must not cross the takeoff board, and in throws, they must not step outside the circle or foul line.

Relays: The baton must be passed within a specific exchange zone.

Scoring
Most track events are decided by time, with the fastest finisher winning the race.
In field events, the winner is determined by the longest valid throw or jump.
In combined events, points are awarded for performance in each event, and the athlete with the highest total score wins.

Athletics tests a wide range of physical attributes, including speed, endurance, power, and agility, making it a core part of major global sporting competitions.

Main Categories of Athletics

Track Events
Sprints (e.g., 100m, 200m, 400m):
Short-distance races that focus on speed.
Middle-Distance Races (e.g., 800m, 1500m): Races that test a combination of speed and endurance.
Long-Distance Races (e.g., 5000m, 10000m, Marathon): Endurance races over longer distances.
Hurdles (e.g., 100m hurdles, 400m hurdles): Runners must clear obstacles placed at regular intervals on the track.
Relays (e.g., 4x100m, 4x400m): Teams of four runners each complete part of the distance before passing the baton to the next runner.

Field Events

Jumps
Long Jump and Triple Jump: Athletes jump for distance after a running start.
High Jump and Pole Vault: Athletes must clear a bar set at increasing heights.

Throws
Shot Put, Discus Throw, Javelin Throw, and Hammer Throw: Athletes aim to throw an object as far as possible.


Combined Events
Decathlon (Men) and Heptathlon (Women): Multi-event competitions that include a combination of track and field events testing overall athletic ability.

Race Walking: Athletes must walk as fast as possible over long distances (e.g., 20km, 50km), maintaining contact with the ground at all times.

variations.title: Sprint 100m
variations.desc: The shortest sprint race, requiring explosive speed over a straight 100 meters.

variations.title: Sprint 200m
variations.desc: A sprint around half the track, combining speed with the ability to navigate the curve.

variations.title: Sprint 400m
variations.desc: A full lap sprint, balancing speed and endurance.

variations.title: Middle-Distance Race 800m
variations.desc: A middle-distance race, typically run in two laps with a focus on speed and strategy.

variations.title: Middle-Distance Race 1500m
variations.desc: A "metric mile" requiring endurance, strategy, and a strong finish.

variations.title: Long-Distance Race 5000m
variations.desc: A long-distance race of 12.5 laps, focusing on endurance and pacing.

variations.title: Long-Distance Race 10 000m
variations.desc: A 25-lap race demanding exceptional endurance and strategic pacing.

variations.title: Marathon
variations.desc: A 42.195 km race, testing long-distance endurance over varied terrain.

variations.title: 110m Hurdles
variations.desc: A sprint with 10 hurdles spaced evenly over 110 meters, requiring speed and precise technique.

variations.title: 400m Hurdles
variations.desc: A full lap race with 10 hurdles, combining sprinting with hurdle technique.

variations.title: 3000m Steeplechase
variations.desc: A race involving barriers and water jumps, testing agility and endurance.

variations.title: 4x100m Relay
variations.desc: A team event with four runners, each sprinting 100 meters, requiring efficient baton exchanges.

variations.title: 4x400m Relay
variations.desc: A team relay where each runner covers 400 meters, with a focus on speed and strategic handovers.

variations.title: 20km Race Walk
variations.desc: A long-distance event where walkers must keep one foot in contact with the ground at all times.

variations.title: 50km Race Walk
variations.desc: An extended race walk requiring significant stamina and technique.

variations.title: High Jump
variations.desc: Athletes leap over a horizontal bar using a Fosbury Flop or other technique.

variations.title: Pole Vault
variations.desc: Competitors use a pole to vault over a bar, requiring strength, speed, and technique.

variations.title: Long Jump
variations.desc: Athletes perform a running leap for maximum horizontal distance.

variations.title: Triple Jump
variations.desc: A sequence of three phases (hop, step, jump) aiming for the longest distance.

variations.title: Shot Put
variations.desc: A throwing event where athletes propel a heavy ball for maximum distance.

variations.title: Discus Throw
variations.desc: Competitors throw a disc for maximum distance using a rotational technique.

variations.title: Hammer Throw
variations.desc: Athletes spin and throw a heavy weight attached to a wire for distance.

variations.title: Javelin Throw
variations.desc: A spear-like javelin is thrown for maximum distance, emphasizing technique and speed.

variations.title: Decathlon
variations.desc: A ten-event competition combining sprints, jumps, throws, and distance events.

badminton.subtitle1: Badminton is a fast-paced racket sport played either in singles (one player per side) or doubles (two players per side). The objective is to hit the shuttlecock over the net and land it in the opponent's court, scoring points when the opponent fails to return the shuttlecock within the boundaries.
badminton.desc1:
Scoring: Matches are typically best-of-three games. Each game is played to 21 points, with players scoring a point on every rally (rally scoring system). A two-point lead is required to win a game, with a cap at 30 points.

Serve: The server must hit the shuttlecock diagonally into the opponent's service box. The serve must be delivered below the waist, and in singles, the serve must land in the narrower service area.

Rallies: Players rally by hitting the shuttlecock back and forth. The rally ends when the shuttlecock touches the ground, goes out of bounds, or fails to cross the net.

Faults: A fault occurs if the shuttlecock is hit into the net, out of bounds, or if the player makes an illegal shot, such as a double hit or carrying the shuttle.



Types of Shots

  • Smash: A powerful downward shot aimed at winning the point.
  • Drop Shot: A delicate shot that just clears the net and drops into the opponent's court.
  • Clear: A high, deep shot that forces the opponent to the back of the court.
  • Drive: A fast, flat shot parallel to the ground.


Singles vs Doubles

  • Singles: Played one-on-one, focusing on speed, stamina, and court coverage.
  • Doubles: Played two-on-two, with greater emphasis on teamwork, strategy, and quick reflexes. The court is wider, and players often specialize in either front or backcourt play.


Court and Equipment

  • Court: A rectangular court divided by a net. Singles courts are narrower (5.18 meters wide), while doubles courts are wider (6.1 meters).
  • Net: Positioned at the center, 1.55 meters high.
  • Shuttlecock: A feathered or synthetic projectile used in place of a ball, designed to decelerate quickly when hit.
  • Racket: Lightweight rackets are used to strike the shuttlecock.


Badminton requires agility, quick reflexes, and excellent hand-eye coordination. It is played internationally at events such as the Olympics, World Championships, and the prestigious All England Open.

variations.title: Singles Badminton
variations.desc:
Event: One player competes against another player.
Competition Method: Each player uses a racket to hit the shuttlecock over the net, aiming to land it within the opponent's court. The match is played in a best-of-three games format, with each game played to 21 points. Players must win by at least 2 points.

Key Rules:
  • Serving: The serve must be diagonal and hit below the server's waist.
  • Scoring: Points are awarded when the opponent fails to return the shuttlecock or hits it out of bounds.

  • Court: The court for singles is 13.4 meters long and 5.18 meters wide.

variations.title: Doubles Badminton
variations.desc:
Event: Two teams of two players each compete against each other.
Competition Method: Teams use rackets to hit the shuttlecock over the net, aiming to land it within the opponent's court. Matches are played in a best-of-three games format, with each game played to 21 points. Teams must win by at least 2 points.

Key Rules:
  • Serving: The serve must be diagonal and hit below the server's waist. Players alternate serving within their team.
  • Scoring: Points are awarded when the opposing team fails to return the shuttlecock or hits it out of bounds.
  • Court: The court for doubles is 13.4 meters long and 6.1 meters wide. The wider width accommodates the extra player on each side.

basketball.subtitle1: Basketball is a fast-paced team sport played on a rectangular court, where two teams of five players each aim to score points by shooting a ball through the opponent's hoop, which is mounted 10 feet high. The team with the most points at the end of the game wins
basketball.desc1:
Court and Equipment:

  • Court: A rectangular surface with two baskets located at each end. Key areas include the three-point line, free-throw line, and the paint (key area).

  • Basket: A metal rim with a net, elevated 10 feet off the ground.

  • Ball: An orange, leather or composite basketball used for dribbling, passing, and shooting.

Key Rules:

  • Scoring:

      • Field Goals: Worth 2 points when made inside the three-point line.

      • Three-Pointers: Worth 3 points when made from beyond the three-point line.

      • Free Throws: Worth 1 point each, awarded for fouls committed during shooting attempts.


  • Game Duration: Typically four quarters, each lasting 12 minutes (NBA) or 10 minutes (FIBA), with overtime played if the score is tied at the end of regulation.


  • Possession and Play:

      • Dribbling: Players must dribble the ball while moving; failure to do so results in a traveling violation.

      • Passing: Players can pass the ball to teammates to advance it or set up scoring opportunities.

      • Shot Clock: Teams must attempt a shot within a specific time (24 seconds in the NBA, 30 seconds in FIBA).


  • Fouls:

      • Personal Fouls: Committed when illegal physical contact occurs, leading to free throws or ball possession for the opponent.

      • Technical Fouls: Given for unsportsmanlike behavior or rule infractions.


Team Fouls: When a team commits too many fouls in a period, the opposing team gets free throws.

boxing.subtitle1: Boxing is a combat sport where two athletes, known as boxers, compete in a ring using only their fists to land punches on their opponent while following a set of strict rules. The primary goal is to outscore the opponent by landing clean punches or to win by knockout (KO), where one boxer is unable to continue..
boxing.desc1:
Key Aspects of Boxing:

  • Rounds and Duration:

      • Professional boxing typically consists of 12 rounds, each lasting 3 minutes, with a 1-minute rest between rounds.

      • Amateur matches often consist of 3 to 4 rounds.

  • Scoring:

      • Judges score each round based on clean, effective punches landed, defensive skills, and ring control. The boxer with the higher score at the end of the match wins, unless the fight ends by knockout or technical knockout.

  • Knockout (KO) and Technical Knockout (TKO):

      • A KO occurs when a boxer is knocked down and cannot rise before the referee counts to ten.

      • A TKO happens when the referee deems a boxer unable to continue the fight, even if they are still on their feet.

  • Protective Gear:

      • Boxers wear padded gloves to protect their hands and limit injury to their opponents.

      • Mouthguards are required to protect the teeth and jaws.

      • Headgear is worn in amateur boxing for additional protection.

  • Weight Classes:

      • Boxers compete in weight divisions to ensure fair competition, ranging from lightweight to heavyweight, each with a specific weight limit.


Tactics and Skills:

  • Offensive Skills: Boxers use jabs, hooks, uppercuts, and body shots to target their opponent.

  • Defense: Effective boxing includes blocking, slipping punches, and footwork to evade strikes.

  • Strategy: Boxers must balance aggression with defense, adapting their style to outmaneuver their opponent.


Boxing requires a blend of physical fitness, mental toughness, and tactical thinking, making it a highly disciplined and strategic sport.

Weight Classes:

  • Lightweight:

    • Boxers in this class are known for their speed, agility, and stamina. They rely on quick footwork, fast combinations, and endurance to outpoint or overwhelm their opponents.

  • Mediumweight:

    • A balance of speed and power defines this class. Boxers here combine tactical precision with the ability to land heavier punches, making their bouts a mix of skill and strength.

  • Heavyweight:

    • Known for their size and knockout power, heavyweights rely on strength and powerful blows. These boxers may be slower compared to lighter categories, but their punches are extremely forceful, often deciding bouts with fewer hits.


Boxing Rules:

  • Matches consist of a series of rounds, typically 3 minutes each, with a 1-minute rest between rounds.

  • A bout can end by knockout (KO), technical knockout (TKO), or by decision, where judges score based on the number of clean punches landed, defense, and ring control.

  • Boxers must wear protective gear such as gloves, mouthguards, and sometimes headgear (in amateur boxing).


Boxing tests endurance, strategy, and precision, with each weight class bringing its own unique style of competition.

canoeing.subtitle1: Water sports involving paddling in a kayak or canoe, emphasizing speed, agility, and technical skill. Events can include sprints on flat water or slalom courses with obstacles.
canoeing.desc1:
Canoeing Disciplines:

  1. Sprint Canoeing:

    • Competitors race in straight-line courses over distances like 200m, 500m, and 1000m.

    • There are two types of boats: Canoes (C), where paddlers kneel and use a single-bladed paddle, and Kayaks (K), where athletes sit and use a double-bladed paddle.

    • Sprint events can be individual (K1, C1), doubles (K2, C2), or teams of four (K4, C4).


  2. Slalom Canoeing:

    • Athletes navigate through a series of gates on a fast-moving river, avoiding penalties for missed or touched gates.

    • Events include single and double competitions (K1, C1, C2).

    • Slalom focuses on precision, timing, and control as athletes maneuver through the course.

Key Elements:

  • Paddling Technique: Efficient paddling is crucial for speed and endurance. In kayaks, both sides of the body are engaged, while in canoes, paddlers use one side.

  • Balance and Core Strength: Maintaining balance in the boat is essential for maximizing speed and control, especially in rough waters.

  • Endurance: Canoe sprints require explosive power, while slalom demands endurance to navigate the technical challenges of the course.

Canoeing is a physically demanding sport that combines strength, endurance, and technique across its varied disciplines.

variations.title: Kayak Single (K1) 200m Sprint
variations.desc:
A fast-paced race for a single kayaker over a 200-meter distance.

Objective: To complete the distance in the shortest time possible.

variations.title: Kayak Double (K2) 200m Sprint
variations.desc:
A team event with two paddlers in a kayak competing over 200 meters

Objective: To finish the race in the fastest time, requiring coordination and teamwork.

variations.title: Kayak Single (K1) 1000m Sprint
variations.desc:
A longer distance race for a single kayaker covering 1000 meters.

Objective: To achieve the fastest time while managing endurance

variations.title: Kayak Double (K2) 1000m Sprint
variations.desc:
A 1000-meter race for two paddlers in a kayak.

Objective: To work together effectively to win the race.

variations.title: Kayak Four (K4) 1000m Sprint
variations.desc:
A team event with four paddlers in a kayak racing over 1000 meters.

Objective: To coordinate efforts for maximum speed and efficiency.

variations.title: Canoe Single (C1) 200m Sprint
variations.desc:
• A single canoe race covering 200 meters.
  • Objective: To complete the distance in the shortest time.

variations.title: Canoe Double (C2) 1000m Sprint
variations.desc:
A race for two paddlers in a canoe over 1000 meters.

Objective: To finish the race in the fastest time through teamwork.

variations.title: Canoe Single (C1) Slalom
variations.desc:
A timed event where a single canoeist navigates through a series of gates on a whitewater course.

Objective: To complete the course in the least time while successfully passing through all gates.

variations.title: Canoe Double (C2) Slalom
variations.desc:
A slalom event for two paddlers in a canoe navigating through gates.

Objective: To navigate the course as quickly and accurately as possible.

cycling.subtitle1: Cycling is a versatile sport that involves racing on bicycles across different terrains and formats. It tests athletes' endurance, speed, technique, and strategic thinking. The sport is divided into four main disciplines: Road Cycling, Track Cycling, Mountain Biking, and BMX, each offering distinct challenges
cycling.desc1:
Cycling Disciplines:

  1. Road Cycling:
      • Road Race: A long-distance race held on open roads, where athletes compete in large groups. The race is often several hundred kilometers, requiring stamina, strategic drafting, and teamwork.
      • Time Trial: A race against the clock over a set distance, usually shorter than a road race. Riders start individually and race for the best time without assistance from teammates.

  2. Track Cycling:
      • Conducted on an oval track called a velodrome.
      • Events include Sprint, where riders cover short distances at high speed, and Endurance Races like the Team Pursuit or Omnium, testing long-term power and strategy.
      • Keirin is a mass-start sprint event where riders are paced by a motorized bike before launching a final sprint to the finish.

    • Mountain Biking:
      • Races are held on rough, off-road terrains with obstacles such as rocks, roots, and steep climbs.

      • Cross-Country Mountain Biking is a popular format, testing endurance, bike-handling skills, and speed over varied terrain


BMX:

  • A fast-paced, high-intensity race on a short, obstacle-filled dirt track.
  • Riders must have explosive power and precise bike-handling skills to navigate jumps, tight turns, and steep inclines.

Key Elements:

  • Endurance: Long-distance races like road and mountain biking require exceptional stamina.
  • Explosive Power: Sprinting events in track cycling and BMX need short bursts of high power.
  • Strategy: Drafting, team tactics, and knowing when to attack or conserve energy are crucial, especially in road races.
  • Technical Skills: Particularly important in track events for timing and precision, and in BMX and mountain biking for handling rough terrain and obstacles.

Cycling is a sport that combines physical endurance, speed, and technical ability, offering a wide range of challenges across its various disciplines.

variations.title: Road Race Cycling (150km)
variations.desc:
• A long-distance race on paved roads, typically featuring varied terrain.
  • Objective: Competitors aim to finish the race in the shortest time, utilizing strategy, teamwork, and endurance.

variations.title: Time Trial Cycling (30km)
variations.desc:
• An individual race against the clock over a fixed distance.
    • Objective: Athletes aim for the fastest time, focusing on aerodynamics, pacing, and technique

variations.title: Sprint Track Cycling
variations.desc:
• A short, intense race on a velodrome, often starting from a standing position.
  • Objective: Riders compete head-to-head over a distance of 200m to 1km, with speed and strategy being crucial.

variations.title: Team Sprint Track Cycling
variations.desc:
• A team event where teams of two or three cyclists race in a sprint format.
  • Objective: Teams aim to complete the distance in the shortest time, with each member taking turns at the front.

variations.title: Keirin Track Cycling
variations.desc:
• A tactical race that begins with a pace bike leading competitors before it pulls off, allowing a sprint finish.

  • Objective: Riders must position themselves strategically for the final sprint, emphasizing tactics and speed.

variations.title: Omnium Track Cycling
variations.desc:
• A multi-event competition featuring various track cycling disciplines.

  • Objective: Points are awarded based on performance in each event, with the overall winner having the highest total points.

variations.title: Team Pursuit Track Cycling
variations.desc:
• Teams of four cyclists race against the clock, working together to achieve the fastest time.

  • Objective: Riders aim to complete the distance as quickly as possible, with coordination and strategy being essential.

variations.title: Cross-Country Mountain Biking
variations.desc:
• A race that combines technical terrain with endurance, often featuring climbs and descents.

  • Objective: Riders aim for the fastest finish time while navigating diverse trails and obstacles.

variations.title: BMX
variations.desc:
• A short, fast-paced race on a dirt track with jumps and obstacles.
  • Objective: Competitors race head-to-head, aiming for the fastest finish, with emphasis on speed, agility, and bike control.

swimrun.subtitle1: An endurance sport that combines swimming and running in a single event, typically held in natural environments such as lakes, rivers, and coastal areas.
swimrun.desc1:
Competition Format

  • Individual and Team Events: Participants can compete solo or in teams, alternating between swimming and running segments.
  • Course Layout: The course usually consists of multiple loops or segments, with a series of transitions between swimming and running.

Rules and Guidelines

  • Gear: Athletes typically wear a wetsuit, and may use paddles, pull buoys, or swim fins during the swimming portions. Footwear is often designed to handle both water and land.
  • Transitioning: There are usually no designated transition areas; athletes move seamlessly from one segment to the next, often carrying their gear.
  • Navigation: Courses may vary in distance and terrain, with some requiring navigation skills through natural landscapes.

Objective

  • The goal of swimrun is to complete the designated course as quickly as possible, showcasing endurance, strength, and versatility in both swimming and running. This sport emphasizes teamwork, strategy, and adaptability to varying conditions.

fencing.subtitle1: Fencing is a fast-paced and strategic combat sport that involves two competitors using swords to score points by touching their opponent. It is known for its rich history, elegant movements, and the mental acuity required to outmaneuver an opponent. Fencing is divided into three main disciplines: Foil, Épée, and Sabre, each with its unique rules and techniques.
fencing.desc1:
Fencing Disciplines:

  1. Foil:
    • A lightweight weapon with a flexible blade.
    • Points are scored by hitting the torso of the opponent, with touches made only with the tip of the sword.
    • Uses a "right of way" rule, where the fencer who initiates an attack has priority in scoring.
  2. Épée:
    • A heavier and stiffer weapon.
    • The entire body is a valid target, and points are scored by any touch made with the tip of the blade.
    • There is no "right of way," allowing both fencers to score simultaneously if they touch each other.
  3. Sabre:
    • A cutting weapon with a slightly curved blade.
    • Points are scored by hitting the upper body, including the head and arms.
    • Also follows the "right of way" rule, similar to foil.

Key Elements:

  • Footwork: Quick and precise movement is essential. Fencers use various techniques, such as advances, retreats, and lunges, to position themselves effectively and evade attacks.
  • Blade Work: Techniques include attacks, parries, and ripostes. Mastery of these skills allows fencers to control the bout's tempo and flow.
  • Strategy and Timing: Fencing is as much a mental game as it is physical. Competitors must anticipate their opponent's actions, make quick decisions, and exploit openings for scoring.
  • Protective Gear: Fencers wear protective clothing, including jackets, masks, gloves, and chest protectors, to ensure safety during bouts.

Competitions:

  • Fencing is featured in various competitions, including the Olympics and World Championships, where athletes compete for individual and team honors.
  • Matches are typically held in a series of rounds, with fencers competing to accumulate points until a set score is reached or time runs out.

Fencing combines athleticism, strategy, and artistry, making it a unique and engaging sport that has captivated audiences for centuries.

variations.title: Individual Épée
variations.desc:
• Event: One-on-one fencing match where fencers use the épée, a heavier sword.
  • Competition Method: Points are scored by hitting any part of the opponent's body with the tip of the sword. The entire body is a valid target area.
  • Key Rules: Double touches are allowed, meaning both fencers can score simultaneously. There's no “right of way” rule, making épée more defensive.

variations.title: Team Épée
variations.desc:
• Event: Team-based épée competition with teams of three fencers.
  • Competition Method: Each fencer on a team faces each fencer from the opposing team. The match continues until one team scores 45 points or time runs out, with the highest-scoring team declared the winner.

  • Key Rules: Like individual épée, double touches are allowed, and there's no right of way.

variations.title: Individual Foil
variations.desc:
• Event: A fencing match using the foil, a lighter sword.
  • Competition Method: Points are scored by hitting the torso with the tip of the sword, excluding the arms, legs, and head.
  • Key Rules: The "right of way" rule applies, meaning points are awarded to the fencer who initiates the attack first, and the target area is restricted to the torso.

variations.title: Team Foil
variations.desc:
• Event: Team competition with three fencers per team, using foil.
  • Competition Method: Each team member faces each opponent until 45 total points are reached or time expires. The team with the most points wins.
  • Key Rules: Right of way applies, and only the torso is a valid target area.

variations.title: Individual Sabre
variations.desc:
• Event: A fast-paced fencing match with the sabre, a sword designed for slashing.
  • Competition Method: Points are scored by hitting the opponent from the waist up with the edge or tip of the sabre. Sabre is the fastest of the three disciplines.
  • Key Rules: Right of way applies, and the valid target area includes the torso, arms, and head.

variations.title: Team Sabre
variations.desc:
• Event: Team competition where each fencer uses the sabre, with three fencers per team.
  • Competition Method: Teams compete until one team reaches 45 points or time runs out. Each fencer faces all members of the opposing team.

  • Key Rules: Right of way applies, and the target area is from the waist up, including the head and arms.

football.subtitle1: Football (or soccer in some countries) is a globally popular team sport played between two teams of eleven players each. It is known for its fast-paced action, strategic gameplay, and passionate fan base. Here's an overview of the sport:
football.desc1:
Basic Overview:

  • Objective: The primary objective of football is to score goals by getting the ball into the opposing team's net while preventing the opposing team from doing the same.
  • Field: The game is played on a rectangular field, typically grass or artificial turf, with a goal at each end. The standard dimensions are approximately 100-110 meters long and 64-75 meters wide.
  • Duration: A standard match consists of two halves, each lasting 45 minutes, with a 15-minute halftime break. Extra time and penalty shootouts may be used to determine a winner in knockout stages.


Key Rules:

  • Offside Rule: A player is considered offside if they are nearer to the opponent's goal line than both the ball and the second-last opponent (usually the last outfield player) when the ball is played to them, unless they are in their own half.
  • Fouls and Free Kicks: Players may not use excessive force or play in a dangerous manner. Fouls can result in direct or indirect free kicks, depending on the nature of the infraction.
  • Yellow and Red Cards: Referees issue yellow cards as warnings for misconduct. Two yellow cards result in a red card, which sends the player off the field. A straight red card may also be given for severe fouls, and the team plays with one less player.
  • Throw-ins, Goal Kicks, and Corner Kicks: When the ball goes out of play, it is restarted via throw-ins (when the ball goes out over the sidelines), goal kicks (when the attacking team touches it last before it goes out over the goal line), or corner kicks (when the defending team touches it last).

Positions:

  • Goalkeeper: The only player allowed to use their hands within the penalty area. Their primary role is to prevent goals.
  • Defenders: Players who primarily focus on stopping opposing attackers and protecting the goal. They include center-backs and full-backs.
  • Midfielders: Players who link defense and attack. They often control the ball and create goal-scoring opportunities.
  • Forwards: Players primarily responsible for scoring goals. They are often the most attacking players on the team.

Competitions:

  • Domestic Leagues: Most countries have a league system where teams compete for the championship. Examples include the Premier League (England), La Liga (Spain), and Serie A (Italy).
  • International Tournaments: National teams compete in international competitions such as the FIFA World Cup, UEFA European Championship, and Copa América.
  • Club Competitions: Teams also compete in international club tournaments like the UEFA Champions League and Copa Libertadores.

Football is celebrated for its ability to bring people together, transcending cultures and languages. It fosters teamwork, sportsmanship, and a sense of community among fans and players alike.

golf.subtitle1: Golf is a precision sport that involves hitting a small ball into a series of holes on a course using as few strokes as possible. It is enjoyed by millions of players and spectators around the world, known for its leisurely pace and emphasis on skill and strategy.
golf.desc1:
Basic Overview:

  • Objective: The goal of golf is to complete a course by hitting the ball into each hole in the fewest number of strokes. The player with the lowest total score at the end of the round wins.
  • Course Layout: A standard golf course typically consists of 18 holes, though there are also 9-hole courses. Each hole has a tee box, fairway, rough, hazards (such as bunkers and water), and a green where the hole is located.
  • Equipment: Players use various clubs, which are categorized into woods, irons, hybrids, and putters. Each club is designed for different types of shots and distances.

Key Rules:

  • Teeing Off: Players start each hole from a designated tee area. The first shot is typically made with a driver or wood club.
  • Stroke Play: In most competitions, players keep track of the total number of strokes taken on each hole. The player with the lowest overall score wins.
  • Course Etiquette: Golf has a strong emphasis on etiquette, including being quiet while others are playing, repairing the course (e.g., replacing divots), and maintaining a reasonable pace of play.
  • Hazards: There are specific rules for playing from hazards such as bunkers (sand traps) and water hazards, which may involve penalties or restrictions on club use.

Formats of Play:

  • Stroke Play: Players count the total number of strokes taken over the course or tournament.
  • Match Play: Players compete hole by hole, with the winner of each hole being the player who takes fewer strokes. The match is won by the player who wins the most holes.
  • Scramble: A team format where each player hits a tee shot, and the best shot is selected for the next stroke, continuing until the ball is holed.

Competitions:

  • Professional Tournaments: Major championships include The Masters, the U.S. Open, The Open Championship, and the PGA Championship. These events attract the world's top golfers and offer significant prize money.
  • Amateur Events: Various amateur tournaments allow non-professional players to compete, including local club championships and national amateur championships.
  • Team Events: Formats such as the Ryder Cup and Presidents Cup feature teams representing different countries or regions competing against each other.

Golf Culture:

Golf is often associated with a relaxed, social atmosphere, with many players enjoying the camaraderie of the game. It promotes physical fitness, mental focus, and a strong sense of sportsmanship. Whether played casually or competitively, golf provides an opportunity for players to enjoy the outdoors and challenge themselves.

gymnastics.subtitle1: Gymnastics is a highly skilled sport that combines strength, flexibility, balance, and coordination. It includes various disciplines that showcase athletic abilities through routines performed on different apparatuses and surfaces. Gymnastics is known for its aesthetic appeal, requiring athletes to perform complex movements with grace and precision.
gymnastics.desc1:
Basic Overview:

Objective: The goal of gymnastics is to perform routines that demonstrate a high level of technical skill and artistry. Athletes are judged based on their execution, difficulty, and overall presentation.

Disciplines: Gymnastics is divided into several disciplines, including:
  • Artistic Gymnastics: Involves routines on apparatuses such as the floor, vault, pommel horse, rings, parallel bars, and horizontal bar for men, and the uneven bars, balance beam, and floor exercise for women.
  • Rhythmic Gymnastics: Combines elements of ballet, dance, and gymnastics, using apparatus like ribbons, hoops, balls, clubs, and ropes. Competitions are performed on a floor without apparatuses or with one or more pieces of equipment.
  • Trampoline Gymnastics: Focuses on performing acrobatic movements while bouncing on a trampoline. Athletes perform routines that include flips and twists.
  • Acrobatic Gymnastics: Features routines performed by groups (pairs, trios, or larger teams), showcasing balance, strength, and flexibility through coordinated moves.


Key Elements:

  • Routines: Gymnasts perform routines composed of various elements that showcase their skills, including jumps, flips, spins, and balance poses.
  • Scoring: Competitions are judged by a panel of judges who evaluate the difficulty and execution of the routine, assigning scores based on predefined criteria.
  • Training: Rigorous training is essential for success in gymnastics. Athletes undergo strength and conditioning programs, flexibility training, and skill development under the guidance of coaches.


Competitions:

  • Individual All-Around: Gymnasts compete in multiple events, and their combined scores determine their overall ranking.
  • Team Competitions: Teams are formed to compete collectively, with the highest-scoring gymnasts contributing to the team score.
  • Major Events: Major competitions include the Olympics, World Championships, and continental championships. These events often showcase the highest level of talent in gymnastics.

Gymnastics Culture:

Gymnastics promotes physical fitness, discipline, and resilience. It emphasizes the importance of dedication and hard work, as athletes often train for many years to master their skills. The sport fosters a strong sense of community, with many athletes forming lifelong friendships through training and competition.



Benefits of Gymnastics:

  • Physical Fitness: Improves strength, flexibility, coordination, and balance.
  • Mental Focus: Enhances concentration and discipline, as athletes must be attentive to their routines and techniques.
  • Confidence: Building skills and achieving goals can boost self-esteem and confidence in athletes.

Whether participating at a recreational level or competing at an elite level, gymnastics provides a unique blend of athleticism and artistry, making it a captivating sport for both participants and spectators.

variations.title: Individual All-Around Artistic Gymnastics
variations.desc:
• Event: Gymnasts perform routines on all apparatus (vault, uneven bars, balance beam, floor exercise).
  • Competition Method: Scores from each apparatus are combined to determine the all-around champion. The gymnast with the highest cumulative score wins.
  • Key Rules: Each routine is judged on difficulty, execution, and artistic performance. A minimum score is required to qualify for the final.

variations.title: Team All-Around Artistic Gymnastics
variations.desc:
• Event: Teams of gymnasts perform routines on all apparatus.
  • Competition Method: Scores from each member's routine on each apparatus are combined to determine the team's total score. The team with the highest cumulative score wins.
  • Key Rules: Teams are usually composed of four to six gymnasts, with the best scores on each apparatus being counted.

variations.title: Floor Exercise Artistic Gymnastics
variations.desc:
• Event: Gymnasts perform a choreographed routine on a spring floor.
  • Competition Method: Routines are performed to music and include a series of tumbling passes, dance elements, and acrobatic movements.
  • Key Rules: Routines are judged on difficulty, execution, and artistic performance. A deduction is given for any errors or lack of synchronization with the music.

variations.title: Men's Pommel Horse Artistic Gymnastics
variations.desc:
• Event: Gymnasts perform a routine on a pommel horse.
  • Competition Method: The routine includes swings, circles, and handstands performed with the hands gripping the pommels or the horse.
  • Key Rules: Judging is based on execution, difficulty, and continuity of movements. Deductions are given for form errors and lack of rhythm.

variations.title: Men's Rings Artistic Gymnastics
variations.desc:
• Event: Gymnasts perform a routine on two rings suspended from a height.
  • Competition Method: The routine includes strength elements, swings, and holds.
  • Key Rules: Judges assess strength, balance, and control. Deductions are given for any instability or form errors.

variations.title: Vault Artistic Gymnastics
variations.desc:
• Event: Gymnasts perform a single explosive jump off a springboard and vault over a horse.
  • Competition Method: The routine consists of a run-up, a vault over the apparatus, and a controlled landing.
  • Key Rules: Judging is based on the difficulty of the vault, execution, and the quality of the landing.

variations.title: Parallel Bars Artistic Gymnastics
variations.desc:
• Event: Gymnasts perform a routine on two parallel bars.
  • Competition Method: The routine includes swings, holds, and transitions between bars.
  • Key Rules: Judges assess the difficulty, execution, and transitions between elements. Deductions are given for form errors and dismounts.

variations.title: Men's Horizontal Bar Artistic Gymnastics
variations.desc:
• Event: Gymnasts perform a routine on a single horizontal bar.
  • Competition Method: The routine includes swings, releases, and complex dismounts.
  • Key Rules: Judging is based on difficulty, execution, and the complexity of release and re-catch skills.

variations.title: Individual Trampoline Gymnastics
variations.desc:
• Event: Gymnasts perform a routine of multiple high-flying acrobatic skills on a trampoline.
  • Competition Method: The routine includes a series of timed jumps and skills, demonstrating height, difficulty, and control.
  • Key Rules: Judging is based on the difficulty, execution, and precision of each skill, with deductions for errors and lack of control.

variations.title: Women's Group All-Around Rhythmic Gymnastics
variations.desc:
• Event: Teams of five gymnasts perform a choreographed routine with a combination of apparatus (hoops, balls, ribbons, clubs).
  • Competition Method: The routine includes coordinated movements and exchanges with the apparatus.
  • Key Rules: Judging is based on difficulty, synchronization, and artistry, with deductions for errors and lack of fluidity.

variations.title: Women's Individual All-Around Rhythmic Gymnastics
variations.desc:
• Event: Individual gymnasts perform routines with different apparatus (hoop, ball, ribbon, clubs).
  • Competition Method: Each gymnast performs routines with each apparatus, with scores from each routine combined to determine the all-around champion.
  • Key Rules: Judging is based on the difficulty of the routine, execution, and artistic expression. A minimum score is required to qualify for the final.

variations.title: Women's Balance Beam Artistic Gymnastics
variations.desc:
• Event: Gymnasts perform a routine on a narrow beam 1.25 meters high.
  • Competition Method: The routine includes acrobatic elements, balance skills, and dismounts.
  • Key Rules: Judging is based on the difficulty of the routine, balance, execution, and precision. Deductions are given for falls, balance errors, and form issues.

handball.subtitle1: A fast-paced team sport played between two teams of seven players (six outfield players and one goalkeeper) who aim to score by throwing a ball into the opposing team’s goal.
handball.desc1:
Basic Overview:

  • Objective: The primary objective is to score more goals than the opposing team by throwing the ball into their net. Players use their hands to pass, dribble, and shoot the ball.
  • Team Structure: Each team consists of seven players (six field players and one goalkeeper). Teams can have substitutes that can rotate in and out during the match.

Game Format:

  • Duration: A standard match consists of two 30-minute halves, with a 10-minute halftime break. If the game ends in a tie during knockout rounds, extra time may be played.
  • Court Dimensions: The handball court measures 40 meters long and 20 meters wide, with a goal area (6-meter line) from which only the goalkeeper can defend against shots.

Key Elements:

  • Gameplay: Players can pass, dribble, and shoot the ball while moving. They can take up to three steps while holding the ball before dribbling or passing. Players must be careful not to double-dribble or hold the ball too long.
  • Scoring: A goal is scored when the ball completely crosses the goal line between the goalposts and under the crossbar.
  • Fouls and Penalties: Physical contact is allowed, but excessive force or dangerous play can result in fouls. Serious fouls can lead to penalties, allowing the opposing team a free shot on goal.

fieldHockey.subtitle1: Field Hockey is a dynamic team sport played on grass or artificial turf, where two teams compete to score goals by hitting a small, hard ball into the opposing team's net using curved sticks. It combines elements of strategy, teamwork, and athleticism, making it one of the most popular sports worldwide, particularly in countries like India, the Netherlands, Australia, and Germany.
fieldHockey.desc1:
Basic Overview:

  • Objective: The primary aim is to score more goals than the opposing team within the match duration. Players use their sticks to pass, dribble, and shoot the ball.
  • Team Structure: Each team consists of 11 players, including 10 field players and one goalkeeper. Teams may have substitutes that can rotate in during the match.

Game Format:

  • Duration: A standard match is played in two halves, each lasting 35 minutes, with a halftime break of about 5-10 minutes. In some tournaments, extra time may be played if the game ends in a tie.
  • Field Dimensions: The field is typically 100 yards long and 60 yards wide, with a 16-yard circle (the shooting circle) in front of each goal.

 

Key Elements:

  • Gameplay: Players can use their sticks to control the ball, pass to teammates, and attempt to score. Players are not allowed to use the flat side of the stick or their body to play the ball, and they must avoid dangerous plays.
  • Scoring: A goal is scored when the ball is hit or pushed into the opponent's goal from within the shooting circle.
  • Fouls and Penalties: Various fouls can result in free hits, penalty corners, or penalty strokes, depending on the severity and location of the foul.

Competitions:

  • Major Events: Field hockey is governed by the International Hockey Federation (FIH), which organizes events like the Hockey World Cup, Hockey Pro League, and Olympic Games.
  • Club and National Leagues: Field hockey also has a strong club structure, with numerous domestic leagues and tournaments taking place globally.

judo.subtitle1: Judo is a modern martial art and combat sport that originated in Japan in the late 19th century, developed by Jigoro Kano. It emphasizes throws, joint locks, and pins, focusing on using an opponent's force and balance against them. Judo is not only a competitive sport but also a way of physical and mental development.
judo.desc1:
Basic Overview:

  • Objective: The primary goal in judo is to either throw or take down an opponent to the ground with force and control, pin them down, or submit them with a joint lock or choke.
  • Practice Format: Judo is practiced on a mat called a "tatami." Training often includes both technical drills and sparring (randori), allowing practitioners to apply techniques in live situations.

Key Elements:

  • Techniques: Judo techniques are divided into three main categories:
    • Nage-waza (Throwing Techniques): Techniques used to throw an opponent, including various grips and footwork.
    • Ne-waza (Ground Techniques): Techniques performed on the ground, including pins, joint locks, and chokes.
    • Kuzushi (Balance Breaking): The principle of off-balancing an opponent to execute throws effectively.
  • Scoring: Points are awarded based on the effectiveness and control of the techniques. A perfect throw (ippon) results in an instant win, while lesser throws (waza-ari) may earn partial points.

Competitions:

  • Major Events: Judo is governed by the International Judo Federation (IJF), which organizes competitions such as the World Judo Championships and the Olympic Games.
  • Weight Classes: Competitions are categorized by weight classes, ensuring fair matches between competitors of similar size.

Belt System:

  • Ranking: Judo practitioners progress through a belt system, starting from white belt (beginner) to black belt (advanced). The black belt has various degrees (dan) that represent higher levels of expertise and understanding.

modernPentathlon.subtitle1: Modern Pentathlon is a multi-sport event that combines five distinct disciplines: fencing, swimming, equestrian show jumping, and a combined event of pistol shooting and cross-country running. It was introduced in the early 20th century and is designed to test a competitor's versatility, endurance, and skill across various sports.
modernPentathlon.desc1:
Basic Overview:

  • Objective: The goal of modern pentathlon is to accumulate the highest score across all five disciplines, showcasing an athlete's overall athletic ability and adaptability.
  • History: The modern pentathlon was inspired by the experiences of a 19th-century cavalry soldier, featuring events that would represent the skills required for survival in a battlefield scenario.

Disciplines:

  1. Fencing:
    • Competitors engage in one-touch bouts using the épée weapon.
    • Each athlete fences against every other competitor, with points awarded for victories.
  2. Swimming:
    • A 200-meter freestyle swim is performed.
    • Swimmers aim for the fastest time, as performance directly impacts overall scoring.
  3. Equestrian Show Jumping:
    • Athletes ride an unfamiliar horse over a course of 12-15 jumping obstacles.
    • Points are deducted for faults such as knockdowns, refusals, and time penalties.
  4. Pistol Shooting:
    • Competitors shoot at a target from a distance of 10 meters using a .177 caliber air pistol.
    • The shooting event typically consists of rapid-fire shots.
  5. Cross-Country Running:
    • A 3,200-meter run that follows the shooting event.
    • Athletes aim to finish as quickly as possible, as the combined score from shooting and running is crucial for the final standings.

Competitions:

  • Format: Modern pentathlon competitions are held in a single day, with all five disciplines typically completed within a few hours.
  • Scoring System: Points are awarded for performance in each discipline, and the overall score determines the winner. The format often includes a "bonus round" for fencing, where competitors can earn additional points.

rowing.subtitle1: Rowing is a water sport that involves propelling a boat using oars. It is both a competitive and recreational activity, emphasizing strength, endurance, teamwork, and technique. Rowing can take place in various types of boats and on different bodies of water, making it a versatile and popular sport worldwide.
rowing.desc1:
Basic Overview:

  • Objective: The primary goal of rowing is to race against other boats over a predetermined distance, completing the course in the shortest time possible.
  • History: Rowing has ancient origins, with evidence of its practice dating back to Egyptian and Greek civilizations. It has evolved into a formal sport with standardized rules and competition formats.

Types of Rowing:

  1. Sweep Rowing:
    • Each rower uses one oar, typically on one side of the boat.
    • Crews can vary in size, including pairs, fours, and eights.
  2. Sculling:
    • Each rower uses two oars, one in each hand.
    • Common boat classes include singles, doubles, and quads.

Boat Classes:

  • Single (1x): One rower.
  • Double (2x): Two rowers.
  • Quad (4x): Four rowers with two oars each.
  • Pair (2-): Two rowers, one oar each, without a coxswain.
  • Four (4-): Four rowers, one oar each, without a coxswain.
  • Eight (8+): Eight rowers, one oar each, with a coxswain to steer and direct.


Competitions:

  • Regattas: Rowing competitions are held at various levels, from local clubs to international championships. Events can be head races or sprint races, with distances commonly ranging from 500 meters to 2000 meters.
  • Olympic Inclusion: Rowing has been an Olympic sport since the inaugural modern games in 1896 for men and in 1976 for women.

Technique:

  • Proper technique is crucial in rowing for maximizing efficiency and speed. Key phases of the rowing stroke include:
    1. Catch: The rower positions the oar in the water at the start of the stroke.
    2. Drive: The rower pushes the oar through the water, using leg and back strength.
    3. Finish: The oar is lifted out of the water, completing the stroke.
    4. Recovery: The rower returns to the catch position, preparing for the next stroke.

variations.title: Single Sculls
variations.desc:
• Event: A single rower propels the boat using two oars (sculling).

  • Objective: Strength, endurance, and technique are key in this solo event over 2000 meters.

variations.title: Double Sculls
variations.desc:
• Event: Two rowers, each using two oars, work in unison to propel the boat.

  • Objective: Requires synchronization, endurance, and power over a 2000-meter course

variations.title: Men's Lightweight Double Sculls
variations.desc:
• Event: Two rowers, each using two oars, in the lightweight category (specific weight limits).

  • Objective: Same as double sculls but with athletes meeting weight restrictions to ensure a level playing field.

variations.title: Quadruple Sculls
variations.desc:
• Event: Four rowers, each using two oars (sculling).

  • Objective: This team event focuses on synchronization and stamina over a 2000-meter distance.

variations.title: Pair
variations.desc:
• Event: Two rowers, each using one oar (sweep rowing), with no coxswain.
